feed.title: Combined summary - Scaling Lightning Safely With Feerate-Dependent Timelocks

entry.title: Combined summary - Scaling Lightning Safely With Feerate-Dependent Timelocks
entry.summary:
Recent discussions among Bitcoin developers have centered on the potential consequences of offchain payments for the network's decentralization and resistance to censorship. Eric Voskuil emphasized the importance of keeping transaction fees within the Bitcoin protocol to prevent mining centralization that could undermine transaction censorship resistance. He suggested relying on accurate in-band fee statistics for the security of solutions like the Lightning Network (LN), coinpools, and channel factories. To mitigate risks associated with variable mining policies and off-chain fees, users are advised to use fee-dependent timelocks set below their maximum acceptable rate.
Developer Dave addressed concerns about enforcing fee-dependent timelocks (FDTs) by pruned full nodes lacking historical median feerate information. He proposed that newly upgraded nodes should collect median feerates for new blocks or download relevant historical data to enforce FDTs effectively. A commitment communication technique in the coinbase transaction was mentioned as well but not adopted due to ASIC miner hardware limitations.
Boris Nagaev raised issues regarding the timing and validation of Fee-Distribution Transactions (FDTs). He pointed out that recent fee changes might not be immediately reflected in transaction confirmations because of aligned windows and proposed a global window size to improve this process.
Technical discussions between Antoine and John focused on the implementation of FDTs, considering parameters such as 'feerate_value_bound,' 'window_size,' and 'block_count' for including transactions in blocks based on median fee rates. These parameters could delay confirmations during high fee periods, addressing Forced Expiration Spam in the LN. They also discussed incorporating FDT parameters into the bip341 annex to benefit both LN channels and factory protocols.
Feerate-Dependent Timelocks (FDTs) emerged as an important development for the Lightning Network, designed to adapt to blockchain conditions and enhance security against "forced expiration spam" attacks. By using dynamic timelocks, FDTs aim to increase the cost for attackers during network congestion. The nSequence field in Bitcoin transactions would be utilized for encoding maximum acceptable fees, ensuring transactions comply with specified fee rates and timelocks, thus preserving network integrity.
The application of FDTs could further extend to channel factories, enabling innovative covenants like HTLC aggregation. Nevertheless, aspects such as miner collusion and the 'claim_grace_period' remain areas of concern that need more analysis to affirm the robustness of FDTs. Despite requiring additional DRAM and computing power, the benefits of FDTs are considered significant enough to propose updates to Bitcoin's consensus rules to incorporate them. Although FDTs cannot guarantee protection against all attack scenarios, they elevate the difficulty of successful double-spend attacks. Developers express optimism for the future implementation and effectiveness of FDTs in tackling key issues within the Lightning Network and related technologies.
